name: NPR
text: Closed restaurants mean empty dumpsters, creating a food shortage for many rats. So they're pushing their search into residential areas — where trash cans are fuller than ever. @hereandnow https://t.co/4kaKoY5rjU

name: NPR
text:
Balls of moss called "glacier mice" persist for years — and move around in a coordinated, herdlike fashion that researchers can not yet explain. 
https://t.co/Mlok1X5RWL

name: NPR
text: Memorial Day is not the same as Veterans Day. https://t.co/gvAKEmdWcL

name: NPR
text: In Afghanistan, an all-girls robotics team is trying to build a mechanized, hand-operated ventilator for coronavirus patients — using parts from old Toyota Corollas. https://t.co/l7wJwOaWIh

name: NPR
text:
Increased demand for acrylic plastic to make sneeze guards is already causing shortages. @hereandnow
https://t.co/WpEdwCHHjL

name: NPR
text:
The owner of a Connecticut nursing home offered staff large bonuses to move into RVs he rented and placed on site. They would quarantine with their patients.

Two months later, there have been no COVID-19 infections at the facility. @hereandnow https://t.co/Gdtj7Tmgxo

name: NPR
text: The film, "Military Wives," follows a group of women who form a choir to cope with their spouses' deployments to Afghanistan. "It's a story that speaks to a huge number of partners, spouses and wives of the military," actor Sharon Horgan says. https://t.co/4UAGFAlvQH

name: NPR
text:
Room Rater (@ratemyskyperoom) says Dr. Anthony Fauci has a great room — though it’s a bit disheveled. 

With stacks of books behind him, it gives off an “absent-minded professor” vibe, creator Claude Taylor says. @hereandnow https://t.co/Q0pvw8VuNN

name: NPR
text: In an open letter, 77 Nobel prize-winning U.S. scientists say they're "gravely concerned" about the abrupt termination of a federal grant for coronavirus research in China — and call for a review of the decision. https://t.co/92A7DiS6QX

name: NPR
text:
A video about the end of the universe inspired @noahcyrus' EP title.

"There's something really terrifying, but also comforting about that, when you think about how much fear and how much hatred there is in the world, and that will also end," she says. https://t.co/nLzJDH8UyL

name: NPR
text: Blending tap dance and zapateado, La Mezcla dance company uses dance and song to tell stories of Chicana history, culture and resistance — such as those who stood up to the racist attacks of the 1943 Zoot Suit Riots. @KQEDarts https://t.co/DPoniKmypg

name: NPR
text: Billy Mills was born on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. After he won gold at the '64 Olympics, he dedicated his life to empowering American Indians — co-founding a nonprofit, Running Strong for American Indian Youth. @OnlyAGame https://t.co/q3cqKIHbdY

name: NPR
text: Here are some of the most effective ways that fans can contribute financially to artists and music-industry workers in need. https://t.co/Iui4u8sGEt

name: NPR
text:
Where are the swabs, and why is testing for the coronavirus so complicated? 
https://t.co/XVcLlJJe9V

name: NPR
text: One researcher says small-scale disruptions are common in the illegal drug trade, but the chaos seen in recent months is nearly unprecedented. https://t.co/1UJFz2HrrY

name: NPR
text:
Linda May Han Oh and Fabian Almazan were already forces to be reckoned with when they were keeping their creative practices separate.

Together, dare we say, they're one of today's premiere jazz power couples.
https://t.co/kfQBSGd9js

name: NPR
text:
Sheltering in place isn't new for kids who live in communities affected by gun violence. 

In St. Louis, they're taught how to drop to the floor if they hear gunfire. That maintains their physical safety.

But addressing the emotional toll isn't as simple. https://t.co/17xrddQhNw

name: NPR
text: Navy nurse Ruth Gunther, who joined up in 1942 and worked treating troops wounded in the Pacific, is among those who are unable to visit this year because of the pandemic. https://t.co/mImmatQdet

name: NPR
text: Thinking about becoming a contact tracer? Here are some helpful tips. https://t.co/k1ZnXFE3Gu

name: NPR
text: Ilhan Omar's new memoir details her childhood in Somalia, followed by civil war, four years in a refugee camp, a journey to the U.S.  — and ultimately being elected as one of the first Muslim women to Congress. https://t.co/46f28yAoBC

name: NPR
text:
U.S. energy-related carbon dioxide emissions are projected to decrease an extraordinary 11% this year.

The question is whether our new energy-saving habits will stick as daily life returns to normal. https://t.co/jPxeuBmHGF

name: NPR
text: Just in: Former Vice President Joe Biden made his first significant trip outside his home in two months today, visi… https://t.co/qSZhnOAdhi

name: NPR
text: President Trump has slammed Biden for campaigning from his basement. Biden has said he is following the Delaware go… https://t.co/XDkmqAx0B0

name: NPR
text: Astronauts have long quarantined before flights, but stay-at-home rules allowed them to spend some of it in their own homes this time. https://t.co/pNqTVYOrJ1

name: NPR
text:
Former NBA player @JLin7 talks about COVID-19 — and the racism Asian Americans have faced during the pandemic.

“Even when I was going to the grocery store, it became so clear that, like, yeah, people were looking at me a certain type of way," he says. https://t.co/OB0nKOh1Zj

name: NPR
text: As Americans observe a subdued Memorial Day, President Trump visited Fort McHenry in Baltimore to remember soldiers who have fallen in service of the country -- as well as those killed by COVID-19. https://t.co/1XLge0FnpM

name: NPR
text: While some families flocked to reopened beaches, many traditional Memorial Day events were scuttled across the U.S. Instead of parades marking the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II, veterans convoyed in cars or visited memorials in face masks. https://t.co/GzpSFPiB7j

name: NPR
text:
New cases in Japan have fallen to dozens per day, and restrictions are being lifted, but many there take issue with how Prime Minister Abe responded to the pandemic. 

One recent survey found his approval rating at a record-low 29%. https://t.co/Up2tWSRSaa

name: NPR
text:
Former vice president Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee, made a Memorial Day trip to a war memorial, where he placed a wreath. 

It was his first official public appearance in 10 weeks as he followed pandemic guidelines to stay home.
https://t.co/lxqX1zA0bF

name: NPR
text: The WHO is suspending a large clinical trial of hydroxychloroquine, citing a report linking the drug to higher death rates in COVID-19 patients. President Trump has advocated its use during the pandemic despite limited research on its effectiveness. https://t.co/VvUrCaJ5Ga
